3hr.clt.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud."
3hr.clt.comment: for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Include both large-scale and convective cloud.  This is a 3-hour mean.

3hr.ficeberg.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.ficeberg.comment: Computed as the iceberg melt water flux into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.
3hr.ficeberg.long_name: Water Flux into Sea Water from Icebergs
3hr.ficeberg.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

3hr.flandice.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.flandice.comment: Computed as the water flux into the ocean due to land ice (runoff water from surface and base of land ice or melt from base of ice shelf or vertical ice front) into the ocean divided by the area ocean portion of the grid cell.
3hr.flandice.long_name: Water Flux into Sea Water from Land Ice

3hr.friver.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.friver.comment: Computed as the river flux of water into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.
3hr.friver.long_name: Water Flux into Sea Water from Rivers

3hr.hfds.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.hfds.comment: Net flux of heat entering the liquid water column through its upper surface (excluding any 'flux adjustment').
3hr.hfds.long_name: Downward Heat Flux at Sea Water Surface

3hr.hfls.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface latent heat flux is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air on account of evaporation (including sublimation). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

3hr.hfrunoffds.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.hfrunoffds.comment: Heat flux associated with liquid water which drains from land. It is calculated relative to the heat that would be transported by runoff water entering the sea at zero degrees Celsius.
3hr.hfrunoffds.long_name: Temperature Flux Due to Runoff Expressed as Heat Flux into Sea Water
3hr.hfrunoffds.processing_note: In general this should be reported as a function of depth, (i.e., it will be a function of the generic "XYZ" dimensions). Include enough depth levels to represent the non-zero values of this field everywhere on the globe. Report on native horizontal grid. If a function of depth, perform online remapping to depth or pressure, if not native vertical grid.

3hr.hfss.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface sensible heat flux, also called turbulent heat flux, is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air by motion of air."

3hr.huss.processing_note:
normally, report at 2 meters above the surface
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude time1 height2m CMIP7:longitude latitude time1  height2m,
 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

3hr.mpw.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.mpw.comment: Average wave period (i.e., time in-between two wave crests) across the entire two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. In spectral wind wave models, it is calculated using spectral moments, mathematical measures that describe the shape and characteristics of the wave spectrum.

3hr.mrro.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
3hr.mrro.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The total run-off (including drainage through the base of the soil model) per unit area leaving the land portion of the grid cell."
3hr.mrro.comment: the total runoff (including "drainage" through the base of the soil model) leaving the land portion of the grid cell divided by the land area in the grid cell, averaged over the 3-hour interval.

3hr.mrros.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

3hr.mrso10.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

3hr.mrsos.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: point
3hr.mrsos.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "The mass of water in all phases in the upper 10cm of the  soil layer."

"frequency" was "3hrPt"
3hr.mrsos.comment: the mass of water in all phases in a thin surface soil layer.
3hr.mrsos.long_name: Moisture in Upper Portion of Soil Column
3hr.mrsos.processing_note:
integrate over uppermost 10 cm

 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

3hr.pr.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "includes both liquid and solid phases"
3hr.pr.comment: at surface; includes both liquid and solid phases.  This is the 3-hour mean precipitation flux.

3hr.prsn.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "At surface; includes precipitation of all forms of water in the solid phase"
3hr.prsn.comment: at surface.  Includes precipitation of all forms water in the solid phase.  This is the 3-hour mean snowfall flux.

3hr.ps.cmip6_differences:
"frequency" was "3hrPt"

"comment" was "surface pressure (not mean sea-level pressure), 2-D field to calculate the 3-D pressure field from hybrid coordinates"
3hr.ps.comment: sampled synoptically to diagnose atmospheric tides, this is better than mean sea level pressure.
3hr.ps.processing_note:
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in CMIP7 Frequency - CMIP6:3hrPt CMIP7:3hr,
 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

3hr.rlds.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

3hr.rlus.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

3hr.rsds.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Surface solar irradiance for UV calculations."

3hr.rsntds.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.rsntds.comment: The radiative flux into the surface of liquid sea water only. This excludes shortwave flux absorbed by sea ice, but includes any light that passes through the ice and is absorbed by the ocean.
3hr.rsntds.long_name: Net Downward Shortwave Radiation at Sea Water Surface

3hr.rsus.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. Upwelling radiation is radiation from below. It does not mean 'net upward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

3hr.sfdsi.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.sfdsi.comment: Basal salt flux into ocean from sea ice. This field is physical, and it arises since sea ice has a nonzero salt content, so it exchanges salt with the liquid ocean upon melting and freezing.
3hr.sfdsi.long_name: Downward Sea Ice Basal Salt Flux
3hr.sfdsi.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid as well as mapped onto sphere.

3hr.swh.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.swh.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This is a key parameter for describing wave energy and is derived from the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wave spectrum.

3hr.tas.processing_note:
normally, report at 2 meters above the surface
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude time1 height2m CMIP7:longitude latitude time1  height2m, Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

3hr.tauuo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.tauuo.comment: The stress on the liquid ocean from interactions with overlying atmosphere, sea ice, ice shelf, etc.
3hr.tauuo.long_name: Sea Water Surface Downward X Stress

3hr.tauvo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.tauvo.comment: The stress on the liquid ocean from interactions with overlying atmosphere, sea ice, ice shelf, etc.
3hr.tauvo.long_name: Sea Water Surface Downward Y Stress

3hr.tslsi.comment: Surface temperature of all surfaces except open ocean, sampled synoptically.

3hr.ua100m.comment: Zonal wind (positive in a eastward direction) at 100m

3hr.va100m.comment: Meridional wind (positive in a northward direction) at 100m

3hr.wdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.wdir.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

3hr.wfo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.wfo.comment: Computed as the water flux into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell. This is the sum \*wfonocorr\* and \*wfcorr\*.
3hr.wfo.processing_note: Net flux of water into sea water, including any flux correction. Report on native horizontal grid as well as mapped onto sphere.

3hr.wpdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.wpdir.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves, by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

3hr.wpp.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hr.wpp.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic waves in total wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across the entire two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves.

3hrPt.mpw.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hrPt.mpw.comment: Average wave period (i.e., time in-between two wave crests) across the entire two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. In spectral wind wave models, it is calculated using spectral moments, mathematical measures that describe the shape and characteristics of the wave spectrum.

3hrPt.swh.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hrPt.swh.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This is a key parameter for describing wave energy and is derived from the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wave spectrum.

"frequency" was "3hrPt"

"comment" was "Eastward component of the near-surface (usually, 10 meters)  wind"

3hrPt.vas.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Northward component of the near surface wind"

"frequency" was "3hrPt"

3hrPt.wdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hrPt.wdir.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

3hrPt.wpdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hrPt.wpdir.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves, by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

3hrPt.wpp.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
3hrPt.wpp.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic waves in total wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across the entire two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves.

6hr.mpw.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.mpw.comment: Average wave period (i.e., time in-between two wave crests) across the entire two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. In spectral wind wave models, it is calculated using spectral moments, mathematical measures that describe the shape and characteristics of the wave spectrum.

6hr.mpwswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.mpwswell.comment: Average wave period (i.e., time in-between two wave crests) of swell waves only (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area). In spectral wind wave models, it is calculated using spectral moments, mathematical measures that describe the shape and characteristics of the wave spectrum.

6hr.mpwwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.mpwwindsea.comment: Average wave period (i.e., time in-between two wave crests) of wind-sea waves only (i.e., local wind waves). In spectral wind wave models, it is calculated using spectral moments, mathematical measures that describe the shape and characteristics of the wave spectrum.

6hr.sduo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.sduo.comment: The eastward component of the net drift velocity of ocean water caused by surface wind-sea waves. The Stokes drift velocity could be defined as the difference between the average Lagrangian flow velocity of a fluid parcel, and the average Eulerian flow velocity of the fluid at a fixed position.

6hr.sdvo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.sdvo.comment: The northward component of the net drift velocity of ocean water caused by surface wind-sea waves. The Stokes drift velocity could be defined as the difference between the average Lagrangian flow velocity of a fluid parcel, and the average Eulerian flow velocity of the fluid at a fixed position.

6hr.swh.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.swh.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This is a key parameter for describing wave energy and is derived from the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wave spectrum.

6hr.swhmax.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: maximum
6hr.swhmax.comment: Highest value of the significant wave height simulated within a given time range (e.g., daily or monthly). The significant wave height (swh) is derived from the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, swh is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wave spectrum.

6hr.swhswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.swhswell.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating just swell waves (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area). This parameter is derived from all swell partitions of the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the components of the two-dimensional wave spectrum that are not under the influence of local wind.

6hr.swhwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.swhwindsea.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating just wind-sea waves (i.e., local wind waves). It is derived from the wind-sea wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wind-sea wave spectrum.

6hr.wdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wdir.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

6hr.wdirswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wdirswell.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the swell component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area). This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

6hr.wdirwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wdirwindsea.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the wind-sea component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., local wind waves). This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

6hr.wpdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wpdir.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves, by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

6hr.wpdirswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wpdirswell.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the swell component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area), by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is typically expressed in degrees relative to true north.

6hr.wpdirwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wpdirwindsea.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the wind-sea component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., local wind waves), by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is typically expressed in degrees relative to true north.

6hr.wpp.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wpp.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic waves in total wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across the entire two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves.

6hr.wppswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wppswell.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic swell waves (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area). In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across part of the two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating just swell waves.

6hr.wppwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
6hr.wppwindsea.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic wind-sea waves (i.e., local wind waves). In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across part of the two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating just wind-sea waves.

6hrPlevPt.zg.comment: Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.

AERday.co.comment: This is the daily mean for CO volume mixing ratio in lowest model layer

AERday.cod.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The optical thickness is the integral along the path of radiation of a volume scattering/absorption/attenuation coefficient. The radiative flux is reduced by a factor exp(-optical_thickness) on traversing the path. A coordinate variable of radiation_wavelength or radiation_frequency can be specified to indicate that the optical thickness applies at specific wavelengths or frequencies. The atmosphere optical thickness applies to radiation passing through the entire atmosphere. 'Cloud' means the component of extinction owing to the presence of liquid or ice water particles. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a  single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase."
AERday.cod.comment: The optical thickness is the integral along the path of radiation of a volume scattering/absorption/attenuation coefficient. The radiative flux is reduced by a factor exp(-optical_thickness) on traversing the path. A coordinate variable of radiation_wavelength or radiation_frequency can be specified to indicate that the optical thickness applies at specific wavelengths or frequencies. The atmosphere optical thickness applies to radiation passing through the entire atmosphere. "Cloud" means the component of extinction owing to the presence of liquid or ice water particles. The specification of a physical process by the phrase due_to_process means that the quantity named is a  single term in a sum of terms which together compose the general quantity named by omitting the phrase.

A chemical species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. Acetone is an organic molecule with the chemical formula CH3CH3CO. The IUPAC name for acetone is propan-2-one. Acetone is a member of the group of organic compounds known as ketones. There are standard names for the ketone group as well as for some of the individual species."

AERmon.emic3h8.comment: This is the total emission rate of propane (C3H8) into the atmosphere

AERmon.emich3oh.comment: This is the total emission rate of methanol (CH3OH) into the atmosphere

AERmon.emich4.comment: This is the total emission rate of methane (CH4) into the atmosphere

AERmon.emidms.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

AERmon.emidust.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

AERmon.emih2.comment: This is the total emission rate of molecular hydrogen (H2) into the atmosphere (i.e., integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field)

AERmon.emiisop.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field

AERmon.emilkch4.comment: This is the emission rate of methane (CH4) into the atmosphere from freshwater lakes

AERmon.emilnox.comment: Integrate the NOx production for lightning over model layer. proposed name: tendency_of_atmosphere_mass_content_of_nox_from_lightning

AERmon.eminh3.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

AERmon.eminox.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "NOx=NO+NO2. Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field."
AERmon.eminox.comment: Store flux as Nitrogen. NOx=NO+NO2. Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

AERmon.emioa.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "This is the sum of total emission of primary organic aerosol (POA) and total production of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) (emipoa+chepsoa). Here, mass refers to the mass of organic matter, not mass of organic carbon alone. We recommend a scale factor of POM=1.4*OC, unless your model has more detailed info available.  Integrate 3D chemical production and emission field vertically to 2d field."
AERmon.emioa.comment: This is the sum of total emission of POA and total production of SOA (emipoa+chepsoa). "Mass" refers to the mass of organic matter, not mass of organic carbon alone. We recommend a scale factor of POM=1.4\*OC, unless your model has more detailed info available.  Integrate 3D chemical production and emission field vertically to 2d field.
AERmon.emioa.long_name: Primary Emission and Chemical Production of Dry Aerosol Organic Matter

AERmon.emiso2.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.

AERmon.emiso4.comment: Direct primary emission does not include secondary sulfate production. Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.
AERmon.emiso4.long_name: Total Direct Emission Rate of SO4

AERmon.emiss.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field.
AERmon.emiss.long_name: Total Emission Rate of Sea-Salt Aerosol

AERmon.emivoc.comment: Integrate 3D emission field vertically to 2d field. _If_ fixed molecular weight of NMVOC is not available in model, please provide in units of kilomole m-2 s-1 (i.e. kg m-2 s-1 as if model NMVOC had molecular weight of 1) and add a comment to your file.

AERmon.h2.comment: This is the mole fraction of molecular hydrogen (H2) in air

AERmon.h2loss.comment: This is the loss rate of molecular hydrogen (H2) from the atmosphere due to chemical destruction

AERmon.h2prod.comment: This is the production of molecular hydrogen (H2) in the atmosphere due to chemical production

AERmon.hcfc22.comment: This is the mole fraction of HCFC22 in air

AERmon.hcho.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

AERmon.hcl.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.  The chemical formula of hydrogen chloride is HCl.

AERmon.hfc125.comment: This is the mole fraction of HFC125 in air

AERmon.hfc134a.comment: This is the mole fraction of HFC134a in air

AERmon.hno3.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

AERmon.isop.comment: Mole fraction of isoprene in air.

AERmon.lossco.long_name: Monthly Loss of Atmospheric Carbon Monoxide

AERmon.lossn2o.long_name: Monthly Loss of Atmospheric Nitrous Oxide

AERmon.lwp.comment: The total mass of liquid water in cloud per unit area.

AERmon.meanage.comment: The mean age of air is defined as the mean time that a stratospheric air mass has been out of contact with the well-mixed troposphere.

AERmon.mmraerh2o.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Mass fraction is used in the construction mass_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y. It means the ratio of the mass of X to the mass of Y (including X). 'Aerosol' means the system of suspended liquid or solid particles in air (except cloud droplets) and their carrier gas, the air itself. 'Ambient_aerosol' means that the aerosol is measured or modelled at the ambient state of pressure, temperature and relative humidity that exists in its immediate environment. 'Ambient aerosol particles' are aerosol particles that have taken up ambient water through hygroscopic growth. The extent of hygroscopic growth depends on the relative humidity and the composition of the particles."
AERmon.mmraerh2o.comment: Mass fraction is used in the construction mass_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y. It means the ratio of the mass of X to the mass of Y (including X). "Aerosol" means the system of suspended liquid or solid particles in air (except cloud droplets) and their carrier gas, the air itself. "Ambient_aerosol" means that the aerosol is measured or modelled at the ambient state of pressure, temperature and relative humidity that exists in its immediate environment. "Ambient aerosol particles" are aerosol particles that have taken up ambient water through hygroscopic growth. The extent of hygroscopic growth depends on the relative humidity and the composition of the particles.

AERmon.mmrbc.comment: Dry mass fraction of black carbon aerosol particles in air.

AERmon.mmrdust.comment: Dry mass fraction of dust aerosol particles in air.

AERmon.mmrnh4.comment: Dry mass fraction of ammonium aerosol particles in air.

AERmon.mmrno3.comment: Dry mass fraction of nitrate aerosol particles in air.

AERmon.mmroa.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "We recommend a scale factor of POM=1.4*OC, unless your model has more detailed info available."
AERmon.mmroa.comment: We recommend a scale factor of POM=1.4\*OC, unless your model has more detailed info available.
AERmon.mmroa.long_name: Total Organic Aerosol Mass Mixing Ratio

AERmon.mmrpm1.comment: Mass fraction atmospheric particulate compounds with an aerodynamic diameter of less than or equal to 1 micrometers

AERmon.mmrpm10.comment: Mass fraction atmospheric particulate compounds with an aerodynamic diameter of less than or equal to 10 micrometers

AERmon.mmrpm2p5.comment: Mass fraction atmospheric particulate compounds with an aerodynamic diameter of less than or equal to 2.5 micrometers

AERmon.mmrso4.comment: Dry mass of sulfate (SO4) in aerosol particles as a fraction of air mass.

AERmon.mmrsoa.comment: Mass fraction in the atmosphere of secondary organic aerosols (particulate organic matter formed within the atmosphere from gaseous precursors; dry mass).
AERmon.mmrsoa.long_name: Secondary Organic Aerosol Mass Mixing Ratio

AERmon.mmrss.comment: Mass fraction in the atmosphere of sea salt aerosol (dry mass).

AERmon.n2o.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.   The chemical formula of  nitrous oxide is N2O.

AERmon.nh50.comment: Fixed surface layer mixing ratio over 30o-50oN (100ppbv), uniform fixed 50-day exponential decay.

AERmon.no.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

AERmon.no2.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

AERmon.o3.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

AERmon.o3inst.comment: This is the mole fraction of ozone in air, sampled on the first day of the month as an instantaneous field.
AERmon.o3inst.processing_note: Note that this variable is an instantaneous field, sampled on the first day of each month, and not time-meaned over the month

AERmon.o3loss.comment: ONLY provide the sum of the following reactions: (i) O(1D)+H2O; (ii) O3+HO2; (iii) O3+OH; (iv) O3+alkenes (isoprene, ethene,...)

AERmon.o3prod.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "ONLY provide the sum of all the HO2/RO2 + NO reactions (as k*[HO2]*[NO])"
AERmon.o3prod.comment: ONLY provide the sum of all the HO2/RO2 + NO reactions (as k\*[HO2]\*[NO])

AERmon.o3ste.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Ozone tracer intended to map out strat-trop exchange (STE) of ozone. Set to ozone in the stratosphere, then destroyed in the troposphere using the ozone chemical loss rate. Please specify the tropopause definition used"

"modeling_realm" was "aerosol"
AERmon.o3ste.comment: Ozone tracer intended to map out strat-trop exchange (STE) of ozone.
AERmon.o3ste.long_name: Stratospheric Ozone Tracer Volume Mixing Ratio

AERmon.pod0.comment: Accumulated stomatal ozone flux over the threshold of 0 mol m-2 s-1; Computation: Time Integral of (hourly above canopy ozone concentration \* stomatal conductance \* Rc/(Rb+Rc) )

AERmon.ptp.comment: 2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature

AERmon.reffclwtop.cmip6_differences:
"standard_name" was "effective_radius_of_cloud_liquid_water_particle_at_liquid_water_cloud_top"

"comment" was "Droplets are liquid only.  This is the effective radius as seen from space over liquid cloudy portion of grid cell. This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, or for some models it is the sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere (TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean. Reported values are weighted by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean."
AERmon.reffclwtop.comment: Droplets are liquid only.  This is the effective radius "as seen from space" over liquid cloudy portion of grid cell. This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, or for some models it is the sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere.TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean. Reported values are weighted by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.

AERmon.so2.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.

AERmon.stratch4loss.comment: This is the loss rate of stratospheric methane by all chemical destruction. The distinction between the stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the tropopause as used in the calculation of the tropopause pressure (ptp). It should have zero values in the troposphere.
AERmon.stratch4loss.long_name: Loss of Stratospheric Methane by all chemical destruction

AERmon.tatp.comment: 2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature

AERmon.tntrl.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Tendency of air temperature due to longwave radiative heating"

"modeling_realm" was "aerosol"
AERmon.tntrl.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Longwave Radiative Heating

AERmon.tntrs.cmip6_differences:
"modeling_realm" was "aerosol"

"comment" was "Tendency of air temperature due to shortwave radiative heating"
AERmon.tntrs.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Shortwave Radiative Heating

AERmon.toz.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Total ozone column calculated at 0 degrees C and 1 bar, such that 1m = 1e5 DU."

AERmon.tropch4loss.comment: This is the loss rate of tropospheric methane by all chemical destruction. The distinction between stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the tropopause used in the calculation of the tropopause pressure (ptp).  It should have zero values in the stratosphere.
AERmon.tropch4loss.long_name: Loss of Tropospheric Methane by all chemical destruction

AERmon.tropch4lossoh.comment: This is the loss rate of tropospheric methane due to reaction with the hydroxy (OH) radical. The distinction between stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp).  It should have zero values in the stratosphere.
AERmon.tropch4lossoh.long_name: Tropospheric loss of methane by OH

AERmon.tropdo3chm.comment: This is the net chemical tendency of ozone in the troposphere. The distinction between the stratosphere and troposphere should be consistent with the definition of the tropopause used in the calculation of the tropopause pressure (ptp). It should have zero values in the stratosphere.
AERmon.tropdo3chm.long_name: Net Chemistry Tendency of O3 in troposphere

AERmon.tropo3ste.comment: Ozone tracer intended to map out strat-trop exchange (STE) of ozone in the troposphere. It represents the ozone volume mixing ratio in the troposphere that is considered to be stratospheric in origin. It should be consistent with the definition of tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp). It should have zero values in the stratosphere and non-zero positive values in the troposphere.
AERmon.tropo3ste.long_name: Tropospheric ozone volume mixing ratio due to stratosphere-troposphere exchange (STE)

AERmon.tropoz.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Tropospheric ozone column, should be consistent with definition of tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp). Calculated at 0 degrees C and 1 bar, such that 1m = 1e5 DU."
AERmon.tropoz.comment: Tropospheric ozone column, should be consistent with definition of tropopause used to calculate the pressure of the tropopause (ptp).

AERmon.ttop.comment: cloud_top refers to the top of the highest cloud. Air temperature is the bulk temperature of the air, not the surface (skin) temperature.

AERmon.ua.comment: Zonal wind (positive in a eastward direction).

AERmon.va.comment: Meridional wind (positive in a northward direction).

AERmon.wa.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). Upward air velocity is the vertical component of the 3D air velocity vector. The standard name downward_air_velocity may be used for a vector component with the opposite sign convention."
AERmon.wa.comment: A velocity is a vector quantity. "Upward" indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). Upward air velocity is the vertical component of the 3D air velocity vector. The standard name downward_air_velocity may be used for a vector component with the opposite sign convention.

AERmon.wetnh3.comment: Surface deposition rate of ammonia (NH3) due to wet processes

AERmon.wetnh4.comment: Surface deposition rate of ammonium (NH4) due to wet processes

AERmon.wetno3.comment: This is the loss rate of nitrate aerosol from the atmosphere due to wet deposition

AERmon.zg.comment: Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.

AERmon.ztp.comment: 2D monthly mean thermal tropopause calculated using WMO tropopause definition on 3d temperature

Amon.ccb.cell_methods: area: time: mean where convective_cloud (weighted by total convective cloud area)
Amon.ccb.comment: Where convective cloud is present in the grid cell, the instantaneous cloud base altitude should be that of the bottom of the lowest level containing convective cloud. Missing data should be reported in the absence of convective cloud. The time mean should be calculated from these quantities averaging over occasions when convective cloud is present only, and should contain missing data for occasions when no convective cloud is present during the meaning period.
Amon.ccb.long_name: Air Pressure at Convective Cloud Base
Amon.ccb.processing_note:

Amon.cct.comment: Where convective cloud is present in the grid cell, the instantaneous cloud top altitude should be that of the top of the highest level containing convective cloud. Amon.ch4.processing_note: For some simulations (e.g., prescribed concentration pi-control run), this will not vary from one year to the next, and so report instead the variable described in the next table entry.  If CH4 is spatially uniform, omit this field, but report Global Mean Mole Fraction of CH4 (see the table entry after the next one).   Are these the preferred units or should it be a unitless fraction?  Should this field be reported instead on model levels?  Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)?

Amon.fco2fos.comment: This is the prescribed anthropogenic CO2 flux from fossil fuel use, including cement production, and flaring (but not from land-use changes, agricultural burning, forest regrowth, etc.)

Amon.fco2fos.processing_note: This is requested only for the emission-driven coupled carbon climate model runs.

Amon.fco2nat.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "This is what the atmosphere sees (on its own grid).  This field should be equivalent to the combined natural fluxes of carbon  that account for natural exchanges between the atmosphere and land (nep) or ocean (fgco2) reservoirs."
Amon.fco2nat.comment: This is what the atmosphere sees (on its own grid).  This field should be equivalent to the combined natural fluxes of carbon (requested in the L_mon and O_mon tables) that account for natural exchanges between the atmosphere and land or ocean reservoirs (i.e., "net ecosystem biospheric productivity", for land, and "air to sea CO2 flux", for ocean.)
Amon.fco2nat.long_name: Surface Carbon Mass Flux into the Atmosphere Due to Natural Sources [kgC m-2 s-1]
Amon.fco2nat.processing_note: Report from all simulations (both emission-driven and concentration-driven) performed by models with fully interactive and responsive carbon cycles.

Amon.n2o.comment: Mole fraction is used in the construction mole_fraction_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.   The chemical formula of  nitrous oxide is N2O.
Amon.n2o.processing_note: For some simulations (e.g., prescribed concentration pi-control run), this will not vary from one year to the next, and so report instead the variable described in the next table entry.  If N2O is spatially uniform, omit this field, but report Global Mean Mole Fraction of N2O (see the table entry after the next one).  Are these the preferred units or should it be a unitless fraction?  Should this field be reported instead on model levels?  Or should we also require either the vertically integrated mole fraction (or mass?) of this species or the vertically integrated globally averaged mole fraction (or mass?)?

Amon.rlds.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

CF3hr.rlds.cmip6_differences:
"frequency" was "3hrPt"

"comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."
CF3hr.rlds.comment: The surface called "surface" means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. "longwave" means longwave radiation. Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called "vector irradiance". In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.

CFday.ccb.cell_methods: area: time: mean where convective_cloud (weighted by total convective cloud area)
CFday.ccb.comment: Where convective cloud is present in the grid cell, the instantaneous cloud base altitude should be that of the bottom of the lowest level containing convective cloud. Missing data should be reported in the absence of convective cloud. The time mean should be calculated from these quantities averaging over occasions when convective cloud is present only, and should contain missing data for occasions when no convective cloud is present during the meaning period.
CFday.ccb.long_name: Air Pressure at Convective Cloud Base

Precipitating hydrometeors are included ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model."

CFday.zg.comment: Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface.

CFmon.clmodis.comment: Percentage of total cloud cover in optical depth categories, as seen by the MODIS instrument simulator. Dimensions of tau (optical depth) and cloud-top pressure are the same used by the ISCCP instrument simulator. This is the equivalent MODIS version of the ISCCP _clisccp _variable.
CFmon.clmodis.processing_note: 7 pressure levels x 7 optical depth levels (x latitude x longitude x time).

CFmon.clmodisice.comment: Percentage ice-cloud cover in optical depth categories, as seen by the MODIS instrument simulator. Dimensions of tau (optical depth) and cloud-top pressure are the same as used by clisccp output from the ISCCP satellite simulator.
CFmon.clmodisice.long_name: MODIS Ice Topped Cloud Area Fraction
CFmon.clmodisice.processing_note: 7 pressure levels x 7 optical depth levels.

CFmon.clmodisiceReff.comment: Percentage ice-cloud cover as seen by the MODIS instrument simulator. Dimensions of cloud IWP (cloud ice water path) and r_eff (effective droplet size).
CFmon.clmodisiceReff.long_name: MODIS Ice Topped Cloud Area Fraction
CFmon.clmodisiceReff.processing_note: 7 IWP levels x 6 effective radius levels.  Metric is further described in [Pincus 2023](https://essd.copernicus.org/articles/15/2483/2023/essd-15-2483-2023-discussion.html)

CFmon.clmodisliquid.comment: Percentage liquid-cloud cover in optical depth categories, as seen by the MODIS instrument simulator. Dimensions of tau (optical depth) and cloud-top pressure are the same used by clisccp (ISCCP simulator).
CFmon.clmodisliquid.long_name: MODIS Liquid Topped Cloud Area Fraction
CFmon.clmodisliquid.processing_note: 7 pressure levels x 7 optical depth levels.

CFmon.clmodisliquidReff.comment: Percentage liquid-cloud cover as seen by the MODIS instrument simulator. Dimensions of LWP (cloud liquid water path) and r_eff (droplet effective radius).
CFmon.clmodisliquidReff.long_name: MODIS Liquid Topped Cloud Area Fraction
CFmon.clmodisliquidReff.processing_note: 7 LWP levels x 6 effective radius levels.

CFmon.cls.comment: Cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column due to stratiform clouds, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

CFmon.cltcalipso.comment: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen by the  Cloud-Aerosol Lidar and Infrared Pathfinder Satellite Observation (CALIPSO) instrument. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

CFmon.cltisccp.comment: Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen by the International Satellite Cloud Climatology Project (ISCCP) analysis. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.  (MODIS). Includes both large-scale and convective cloud.

CFmon.cltmodis.comment: Percentage of total cloud cover as seen by the MODIS instrument simulator.
CFmon.cltmodis.processing_note: Latitude x longitude x time. NOTE: Both of the entries in _Coordinates_ and _Extra Dimensions_ should be ignored as they were only included for form submission.

CFmon.clwc.comment: Calculated as the mass of convective cloud liquid water in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cell.  This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.
CFmon.clwc.long_name: Mass Fraction of Convective Cloud Liquid Water

CFmon.clws.comment: Calculated as the mass of stratiform cloud liquid water in the grid cell divided by the mass of air (including the water in all phases) in the grid cell.  This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.
CFmon.clws.long_name: Mass Fraction of Stratiform Cloud Liquid Water

CFmon.clwvimodis.comment: Mass of condensed (liquid + ice) water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column) as seen by the MODIS instrument simulator.

CFmon.dmc.comment: The net mass flux  represents the difference between the updraft and downdraft components.   This is calculated as the convective mass flux divided by the area of the whole grid cell (not just the area of the cloud).
CFmon.dmc.processing_note: Report on model half-levels (i.e., model layer bounds and not standard pressures).

CFmon.edt.comment: Vertical diffusion coefficient for temperature due to parametrised eddies

CFmon.mcu.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. The atmosphere convective mass flux is the vertical transport of mass for a field of cumulus clouds or thermals, given by the product of air density and vertical velocity. For an area-average, cell_methods should specify whether the average is over all the area or the area of updrafts only."

CFmon.tnhusa.comment: Tendency of Specific Humidity due to Advection
CFmon.tnhusa.long_name: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Advection

CFmon.tnhusc.long_name: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Convection

CFmon.tnhusd.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Tendency of specific humidity due to numerical diffusion.This includes any horizontal or vertical numerical moisture diffusion not associated with the parametrized moist physics or the resolved dynamics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be excluded, as should any diffusion which is included in the terms from the resolved dynamics.   This term is required to check the closure of the moisture budget."
CFmon.tnhusd.comment: This includes any horizontal or vertical numerical moisture diffusion not associated with the parametrized moist physics or the resolved dynamics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be excluded, as should any diffusion which is included in the terms from the resolved dynamics.   This term is required to check the closure of the moisture budget.
CFmon.tnhusd.long_name: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Numerical Diffusion

CFmon.tnhusmp.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Tendency of specific humidity due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized moist physics (e.g. convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.) and excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics or from horizontal or vertical numerical diffusion not associated with model physics.  For example any diffusive mixing by the boundary layer scheme would be included."
CFmon.tnhusmp.comment: This includes sources and sinks from parametrized moist physics (e.g. convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.) and excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics or from horizontal or vertical numerical diffusion not associated with model physicsl.  For example any diffusive mixing by the boundary layer scheme would be included.
CFmon.tnhusmp.long_name: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Model Physics

CFmon.tnhusscpbl.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing  (to be specified only in  models which do not separate budget terms for stratiform cloud, precipitation and boundary layer schemes.  Includes all boundary layer terms including and diffusive terms.)"
CFmon.tnhusscpbl.comment: To be specified only in  models which do not separate budget terms for stratiform cloud, precipitation and boundary layer schemes.  Includes all bounday layer terms including and diffusive terms.
CFmon.tnhusscpbl.long_name: Tendency of Specific Humidity Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing

CFmon.tnta.comment: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Advection
CFmon.tnta.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Advection

CFmon.tntc.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Convection

CFmon.tntmp.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget."
CFmon.tntmp.comment: This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). It excludes sources and sinks from resolved dynamics and numerical diffusion not associated with parametrized physics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be included, while numerical diffusion applied in addition to physics or resolved dynamics should be excluded.  This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget.
CFmon.tntmp.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Model Physics

CFmon.tntr.comment: Tendency of Air Temperature due to Radiative Heating
CFmon.tntr.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Radiative Heating

CFmon.tntscpbl.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing (to be specified only in  models which do not separate cloud, precipitation and boundary layer terms.  Includes all boundary layer terms including diffusive ones.)"
CFmon.tntscpbl.comment: To be specified only in  models which do not separate cloud, precipitation and boundary layer terms.  Includes all boundary layer terms including diffusive ones.
CFmon.tntscpbl.long_name: Tendency of Air Temperature Due to Stratiform Cloud and Precipitation and Boundary Layer Mixing

CFsubhr.ccb.comment: Where convective cloud is present in the grid cell, the instantaneous cloud base altitude should be that of the bottom of the lowest level containing convective cloud. Missing data should be reported in the absence of convective cloud. The time mean should be calculated from these quantities averaging over occasions when convective cloud is present only, and should contain missing data for occasions when no convective cloud is present during the meaning period.
CFsubhr.ccb.long_name: Air Pressure at Convective Cloud Base
CFsubhr.ccb.processing_note:
This table includes the 2-D variables listed in the "Amon" spreadsheet, omitting, however, the daily maximum and minimum temperatures.  All variables should be reported as synoptic fields, not daily means.

CFsubhr.cct.comment: Where convective cloud is present in the grid cell, the instantaneous cloud top altitude should be that of the top of the highest level containing convective cloud. Missing data should be reported in the absence of convective cloud. CFsubhr.rlds.cmip6_differences:
"frequency" was "subhrPt"

"comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'longwave' means longwave radiation. Downwelling radiation is radiation from above. It does not mean 'net downward'. When thought of as being incident on a surface, a radiative flux is sometimes called 'irradiance'. In addition, it is identical with the quantity measured by a cosine-collector light-meter and sometimes called 'vector irradiance'. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

CFsubhr.tnhusd.cmip6_differences:
"frequency" was "subhrPt"

"comment" was "Tendency of specific humidity due to numerical diffusion.This includes any horizontal or vertical numerical moisture diffusion not associated with the parametrized moist physics or the resolved dynamics.  For example, any vertical diffusion which is part of the boundary layer mixing scheme should be excluded, as should any diffusion which is included in the terms from the resolved dynamics.   This term is required to check the closure of the moisture budget."
CFsubhr.tnhusd.comment: This includes any horizontal or vertical numerical moisture diffusion not associated with the parametrized moist physics or the resolved dynamics. This term is required to check the closure of the moisture budget.

For example any diffusive mixing by the boundary layer scheme would be included."

CFsubhr.tntmp.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Tendency of air temperature due to model physics. This includes sources and sinks from parametrized physics (e.g. radiation, convection, boundary layer, stratiform condensation/evaporation, etc.). This term is required to check the closure of the heat budget."

Eday.ccldncl.comment: Droplets are liquid only.  Report concentration 'as seen from space' over convective liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, it is better to sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean.
Eday.ccldncl.long_name: Cloud Droplet Number Concentration of Convective Cloud Tops

Eday.cldnci.comment: Concentration 'as seen from space' over ice-cloud portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with ice cloud or, if available, it is the sum over all ice cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Weight by total ice cloud top fraction (as seen from TOA) of each time sample when computing monthly mean.
Eday.cldnci.long_name: Ice Crystal Number Concentration of Cloud Tops

Eday.cldnvi.comment: Droplets are liquid only.  Values are weighted by liquid cloud fraction in each layer when vertically integrating, and for monthly means the samples are weighted by total liquid cloud fraction (as seen from TOA).

Eday.clivic.comment: calculate mass of convective ice water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). This includes precipitating frozen hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

Eday.clt.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.clt.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Total cloud area fraction (reported as a percentage) for the whole atmospheric column, as seen from the surface or the top of the atmosphere. Includes both large-scale and convective cloud."

Eday.clwvic.comment: calculate mass of convective condensed (liquid + ice) water in the column divided by the area of the column (not just the area of the cloudy portion of the column). This includes precipitating hydrometeors ONLY if the precipitating hydrometeors affect the calculation of radiative transfer in model.

Eday.dcw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.dcw.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The phrase 'change_over_time_in_X' means change in a quantity X over a time-interval, which should be defined by the bounds of the time coordinate. 'Canopy' means the plant or vegetation canopy. Canopy water is the water on the canopy. 'Water' means water in all phases, including frozen, i.e. ice and snow. 'Amount' means mass per unit area."

Eday.dgw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.dgw.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Groundwater is subsurface water below the depth of the water table."

Eday.drivw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.drivw.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Change over time of the mass of water per unit area in the fluvial system (stream and floodplain)."

Eday.dslw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.dslw.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The phrase 'change_over_time_in_X' means change in a quantity X over a time-interval, which should be defined by the bounds of the time coordinate. 'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The mass content of water in soil refers to the vertical integral from the surface down to the bottom of the soil model. For the content between specified levels in the soil, standard names including 'content_of_soil_layer' are used. 'Water' means water in all phases."

Eday.dsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.dsn.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Change in time of the mass per unit area of ice in glaciers, ice caps, ice sheets and shelves, river and lake ice, any other ice on a land surface, such as frozen flood water, and snow lying on such ice or on the land surface."

Eday.dsw.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.dsw.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The phrase 'land_water_amount', often known as 'Terrestrial Water Storage', includes: surface liquid water (water in rivers, wetlands, lakes, reservoirs, rainfall intercepted by the canopy); surface ice and snow (glaciers, ice caps, grounded ice sheets not displacing sea water, river and lake ice, other surface ice such as frozen flood water, snow lying on the surface and intercepted by the canopy); subsurface water (liquid and frozen soil water, groundwater)."

Eday.esn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.esn.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Water here means water in all phases. Evaporation is the conversion of liquid or solid into vapor. (The conversion of solid alone into vapor is called 'sublimation'.) In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics. Unless indicated in the cell_methods attribute, a quantity is assumed to apply to the whole area of each horizontal grid box. Previously, the qualifier where_type was used to specify that the quantity applies only to the part of the grid box of the named type.  Names containing the where_type qualifier are deprecated and newly created data should use the cell_methods attribute to indicate the horizontal area to which the quantity applies."

Eday.evspsbl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.evspsbl.comment: Evaporation at surface (also known as evapotranspiration): flux of water into the atmosphere due to conversion of both liquid and solid phases to vapor (from underlying surface and vegetation)

Eday.evspsblpot.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.evspsblpot.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "at surface; potential flux of water into the atmosphere due to conversion of both liquid and solid phases to vapor (from underlying surface and vegetation)"

Eday.evspsblsoi.comment: Water evaporation flux from soil but for daily averages i.e., the evspsblsoi variable, which is only currently defined for monthly averages
Eday.evspsblsoi.long_name: Daily water evaporation flux from soil

Eday.evspsblveg.comment: The same as the current variable evspsblveg but defined on daily timescales.
Eday.evspsblveg.long_name: Daily water evaporation flux from canopy

Eday.flashrate.processing_note: frequency of lightning flashes per unit area

Eday.gppVgt.comment: The rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors by autotrophs ("producers") expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. For example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton. The producers also respire some of this biomass and the difference is referred to as the net primary production. Reported on land-use tiles.
Eday.gppVgt.long_name: Gross Primary Production on Vegetation type as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

Eday.hfdsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.hfdsn.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "the net downward heat flux from the atmosphere into the snow that lies on land divided by the land area in the grid cell; reported as 0.0 for snow-free land regions or where the land fraction is 0."

"modeling_realm" was "landIce land"
Eday.hfdsn.comment: Downward heat flux at snow top
Eday.hfdsn.long_name: Downward Heat Flux into Snow Where Land over Land
Eday.hfdsn.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Modeling Realm - CMIP6:land, landIce CMIP7:land, ocean,

Eday.hfdsnb.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.hfdsnb.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Heat flux from snow into the ice or land under the snow."
Eday.hfdsnb.comment: Downward heat flux at snow botton
Eday.hfdsnb.long_name: Downward Heat Flux at Snow Base

Eday.hursminCrop.cell_methods: area: mean where crops time: minimum within days time: mean over days

"cell_methods" was "area: mean where crops time: minimum"
Eday.hursminCrop.comment: The relative humidity with respect to liquid water for T> 0 C, and with respect to ice for T<0 C.
Eday.hursminCrop.long_name: Daily Minimum Near-Surface Relative Humidity over Crop Tile
Eday.hursminCrop.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: mean where crops time: minimum CMIP7:area: mean where crops time: minimum within days time: mean over days, CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude time height2m CMIP7:longitude latitude time1 height2m,

Eday.hus.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Specific humidity is the mass fraction of water vapor in (moist) air."
Eday.hus.comment: These are standard variables from CMIP5.

Eday.intuadse.comment: Vertically integrated eastward dry static energy transport (cp.T +zg).v (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of eastward wind by dry static_energy per mass unit)
Eday.intuadse.long_name: Vertically Integrated Eastward Dry Static Energy Transport

Eday.intuaw.comment: Vertically integrated eastward moisture transport (Mass weighted vertical integral of the product of eastward wind by total water mass per unit mass)

Eday.intvadse.comment: Vertically integrated northward dry static energy transport (cp.T +zg).v (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of northward wind by dry static_energy per mass unit)
Eday.intvadse.long_name: Vertically Integrated Northward Dry Static Energy Transport

Eday.intvaw.comment: Vertically integrated northward moisture transport (Mass_weighted_vertical integral of the product of northward wind by total water mass per unit mass)

Eday.jpdftaureicemodis.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Joint probability distribution function, giving probability of cloud as a function of optical thickness and particle size, as measured by MODIS. For cloud ice particles."

"standard_name" was "cloud_area_fraction_in_atmosphere_layer"
Eday.jpdftaureicemodis.comment: MODIS Optical Thickness-Particle Size joint  distribution, ice
Eday.jpdftaureicemodis.long_name: MODIS Joint Distribution of Optical Thickness and Particle Size, Ice

Eday.jpdftaureliqmodis.cmip6_differences:
"standard_name" was "cloud_area_fraction_in_atmosphere_layer"

"comment" was "Joint probability distribution function, giving probability of cloud as a function of optical thickness and particle size, as measured by MODIS. For liquid cloud particles."
Eday.jpdftaureliqmodis.comment: MODIS Optical Thickness-Particle Size joint  distribution, liquid
Eday.jpdftaureliqmodis.long_name: MODIS Optical Thickness-Particle Size Joint Distribution, Liquid
Eday.jpdftaureliqmodis.processing_note:
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude effectRadLi tau time CMIP7:longitude latitude time effectRadLi tau,
 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

Eday.lai.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.lai.comment: A ratio obtained by dividing the total upper leaf surface area of vegetation by the (horizontal) surface area of the land on which it grows.

Eday.laiVgt.comment: A ratio obtained by dividing the total upper leaf surface area of vegetation by the (horizontal) surface area of the land on which it grows.
Eday.laiVgt.long_name: Leaf Area Index on Vegetation type

Eday.loadbc.comment: The total dry mass of black carbon aerosol particles per unit area.

Eday.loaddust.comment: The total dry mass of dust aerosol particles per unit area.

Eday.loadnh4.comment: The total dry mass of ammonium aerosol particles per unit area.

Eday.loadno3.comment: The total dry mass of nitrate aerosol particles per unit area.

Eday.loadoa.comment: atmosphere dry organic content: This is the vertically integrated sum of atmosphere_primary_organic_content and atmosphere_secondary_organic_content (see next two table entries).
Eday.loadoa.long_name: Load of Dry Aerosol Organic Matter

Eday.loadpoa.comment: The total dry mass of primary particulate organic aerosol particles per unit area.
Eday.loadpoa.long_name: Load of Dry Aerosol Primary Organic Matter

Eday.loadso4.comment: The total dry mass of sulfate aerosol particles per unit area.

Eday.loadsoa.comment: The total dry mass of secondary particulate organic aerosol particles per unit area.
Eday.loadsoa.long_name: Load of Dry Aerosol Secondary Organic Matter

Eday.loadss.comment: The total dry mass of sea salt aerosol particles per unit area.

Eday.lwsnl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.lwsnl.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "The total mass of liquid water contained interstitially within the whole depth of the snow layer of the land portion of a grid cell divided by the area of the land portion of the cell."

"modeling_realm" was "landIce land"
Eday.lwsnl.long_name: Liquid Water Content of Snow Layer
Eday.lwsnl.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Modeling Realm - CMIP6:land, landIce CMIP7:land, ocean,

Eday.mlotst.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Eday.mlotst.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Sigma T is potential density referenced to ocean surface."

"dimensions" was "longitude latitude time"
Eday.mlotst.comment: Sigma T is potential density referenced to ocean surface. Defined by Sigma T of 0.03 kg m-3 wrt to model level closest to 10 m depth.
Eday.mlotst.long_name: Ocean Mixed Layer Thickness Defined by Sigma T
Eday.mlotst.processing_note: dsigmat coordinate added to clarify definition. CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude time CMIP7:longitude latitude time deltasigt,

Eday.mrro.comment: The total run-off (including drainage through the base of the soil model) per unit area leaving the land portion of the grid cell.

Eday.mrrob.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrrob.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Runoff is the liquid water which drains from land. If not specified, 'runoff' refers to the sum of surface runoff and subsurface drainage. In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

Eday.mrros.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrros.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The total surface run off leaving the land portion of the grid cell (excluding drainage through the base of the soil model)."

Eday.mrsfl.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrsfl.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "in each soil layer, the mass of water in ice phase.  Reported as 'missing' for grid cells occupied entirely by 'sea'"
Eday.mrsfl.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in ice phase.  Reported as "missing" for grid cells occupied entirely by "sea"
Eday.mrsfl.long_name: Frozen Water Content of Soil Layer

Eday.mrsll.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrsll.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "in each soil layer, the mass of water in liquid phase.  Reported as 'missing' for grid cells occupied entirely by 'sea'"
Eday.mrsll.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in liquid phase.  Reported as "missing" for grid cells occupied entirely by "sea"
Eday.mrsll.long_name: Liquid Water Content of Soil Layer

Eday.mrso10.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrso10.comment: Soil moisture in the top 10 cm of the soil column

Eday.mrsol.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrsol.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "in each soil layer, the mass of water in all phases, including ice.  Reported as 'missing' for grid cells occupied entirely by 'sea'"
Eday.mrsol.comment: in each soil layer, the mass of water in all phases, including ice.  Reported as "missing" for grid cells occupied entirely by "sea"
Eday.mrsol.long_name: Total Water Content of Soil Layer

Eday.mrsow.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrsow.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Vertically integrated soil moisture divided by maximum allowable soil moisture above wilting point."

Eday.mrtws.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.mrtws.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Mass of water in all phases and in all components including soil, canopy, vegetation, ice sheets, rivers and ground water."

Eday.nppVgt.comment: "Production of carbon" means the production of biomass expressed as the mass of carbon which it contains. Net primary production is the excess of gross primary production (rate of synthesis of biomass from inorganic precursors) by autotrophs ("producers"), for example, photosynthesis in plants or phytoplankton, over the rate at which the autotrophs themselves respire some of this biomass. "Productivity" means production per unit area. The phrase "expressed_as" is used in the construction A_expressed_as_B, where B is a chemical constituent of A. It means that the quantity indicated by the standard name is calculated solely with respect to the B contained in A, neglecting all other chemical constituents of A.
Eday.nppVgt.long_name: Net Primary Production on Vegetation type as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

Eday.parasolRefl.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Eday.parasolRefl.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Simulated reflectance from PARASOL as seen at the top of the atmosphere for 5 solar zenith angles. Valid only over ocean and for one viewing direction (viewing zenith angle of 30 degrees and relative azimuth angle 320 degrees)."
Eday.parasolRefl.processing_note:
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude sza5 time CMIP7:longitude latitude time sza5,
 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

Eday.pflw.long_name: Liquid Water Content of Permafrost Layer
Eday.pflw.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Modeling Realm - CMIP6:land, landIce CMIP7:land, ocean,

"comment" was "In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."
Eday.prhmax.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: mean time: mean within hours time: maximum over hours CMIP7:area: mean time: maximum,

Eday.prra.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.prra.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."

Eday.prrsn.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.prrsn.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The fraction of the grid averaged rainfall which falls on the snow pack"

Eday.prsnc.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean

Eday.prsnsn.long_name: Fraction of Snowfall (Including Hail and Graupel) on Snow

Eday.prw.comment: vertically integrated through the atmospheric column

Eday.qgwr.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.qgwr.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Mass flux of water from the soil layer into ground water."

Eday.raVgt.comment: Carbon mass flux per unit area into atmosphere due to autotrophic respiration on land (respiration by producers) [see rh for heterotrophic production]. Calculated on vegetation type.
Eday.raVgt.long_name: Autotrophic Respiration on Vegetation type as Carbon Mass Flux [kgC m-2 s-1]

Eday.reffcclwtop.cell_methods: area: time: mean where convective_cloud (weighted by total convective cloud area)
Eday.reffcclwtop.cmip6_differences:
"standard_name" was "effective_radius_of_convective_cloud_liquid_water_particle_at_convective_liquid_water_cloud_top"

"comment" was "Droplets are liquid only.  This is the effective radius 'as seen from space' over convective liquid cloudy portion of grid cell.  This is the value from uppermost model layer with liquid cloud or, if available, or for some models it is the sum over all liquid cloud tops, no matter where they occur, as long as they are seen from the top of the atmosphere. Eday.rzwc.cell_methods: area: mean where land time: mean
Eday.rzwc.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "'Content' indicates a quantity per unit area. The content of a soil layer is the vertical integral of the specified quantity within the layer. The quantity with standard name mass_content_of_water_in_soil_layer_defined_by_root_depth is the vertical integral between the surface and the depth to which plant roots penetrate. A coordinate variable or scalar coordinate variable with standard name root_depth can be used to specify the extent of the layer. 'Water' means water in all phases."

Weight by total liquid cloud top fraction of  (as seen from TOA) each time sample when computing monthly mean."

The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Surface snow and ice refreezing flux' means the mass flux of surface  meltwater which refreezes within the snow or firn."

Eday.t20d.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "This quantity, sometimes called the 'isotherm depth', is the depth (if it exists) at which the sea water potential temperature equals some specified value. This value should be specified in a scalar coordinate variable. Depth is the vertical distance below the surface. Potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of air or sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure."

Eday.zg.comment: Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. "comment" was "Geopotential is the sum of the specific gravitational potential energy relative to the geoid and the specific centripetal potential energy. Geopotential height is the geopotential divided by the standard acceleration due to gravity. It is numerically similar to the altitude (or geometric height) and not to the quantity with standard name height, which is relative to the surface."

Emon.albsrfc.processing_note: There is a variable AERmon.albsrfc, but I am not sure whether the definition applies to the description above; furthermore, the variable would also be of relevance outside of the AER focus, hence we may consider whether it should go into another category as well (I had Emon in mind.); Whether this variable should be provided at atmosphere/land or ocean grid, and the respective grid cell metrics, must be discussed.
