Omon.nh4.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.nh4.comment: Mole concentration means moles (amount of substance) per unit volume and is used in the construction mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y, where X is a material constituent of Y.
Omon.nh4.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.o2sat.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "'Mole concentration at saturation' means the mole concentration in a saturated solution. Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'."
Omon.o2sat.comment: "Mole concentration at saturation" means the mole concentration in a saturated solution. Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called "molarity", and is used in the construction "mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y", where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as "nitrogen" or a phrase such as "nox_expressed_as_nitrogen".
Omon.o2sat.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.obvfsq.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.obvfsq.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The phrase 'square_of_X' means X*X. Frequency is the number of oscillations of a wave per unit time. Brunt-Vaisala frequency is also sometimes called 'buoyancy frequency' and is a measure of the vertical stratification of the medium."
Omon.obvfsq.comment: The phrase "square_of_X" means X\*X. Frequency is the number of oscillations of a wave per unit time. Brunt-Vaisala frequency is also sometimes called "buoyancy frequency" and is a measure of the vertical stratification of the medium.
Omon.obvfsq.long_name: Square of Brunt Vaisala Frequency in Sea Water
Omon.obvfsq.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid as well as on a spherical latitude/longitude grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Omon.ocfriver.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.ocfriver.comment: Organic Carbon supply to ocean through runoff (separate from gas exchange)
Omon.ocfriver.long_name: Flux of Organic Carbon into Ocean Surface by Runoff
Omon.ocfriver.processing_note:
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude time depth0m CMIP7:longitude latitude time  depth0m,
 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

Omon.pbo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.pbo.cmip6_differences:
"dimensions" was "longitude latitude time"

"comment" was "'Sea water pressure' is the pressure that exists in the medium of sea water.  It includes the pressure due to overlying sea water, sea ice, air and any other medium that may be present."
Omon.pbo.comment: "Sea water pressure" is the pressure that exists in the medium of sea water.  It includes the pressure due to overlying sea water, sea ice, air and any other medium that may be present.
Omon.pbo.long_name: Sea Water Pressure at Sea Floor
Omon.pbo.processing_note:
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6: Spatial shape updated to sea floor
CMIP5 had units of dbar.  CMIP6 uses Pa. Report on native horizontal grid as well as on a spherical latitude/longitude grid.
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude time CMIP7:longitude latitude depthseafloor time,

Omon.pfscint.comment: This is a fundamental aspect of the changes in the hydrological cycle and their impact on the oceans, and due to new numerical schemes and vertical discretizations, it is important to calculate it consistently with the model formulation.
Omon.pfscint.long_name: Integral wrt depth of seawater preformed salinity expressed as salt mass content
Omon.pfscint.processing_note: CHANGE: This is a new variable, which aids in understanding hydrological change. It is preferable to calculate it online, due to difficulties with vertical discretizations. It is calculated as an integral over hydrostatic pressure ranges, which makes it directly comparable with observations.

Omon.ph.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.ph.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "negative log of hydrogen ion concentration with the concentration expressed as mol H kg-1."
Omon.ph.comment: negative log10 of hydrogen ion concentration with the concentration expressed as mol H kg-1.
Omon.ph.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.phcint.comment: This is the vertically-integrated heat content derived from potential temperature (thetao).
Omon.phcint.long_name: Integrated Ocean Heat Content from Potential Temperature
Omon.phcint.processing_note: CHANGE: This is a new variable, which aids in calculation of energy budgets.  It is preferable to calculate it online, due to difficulties with vertical discretizations.  It is calculated as an integral over hydrostatic pressure ranges, which makes it directly comparable with observations so long as integrals are over 0-300m, 300m-700m, 700m-2000m, total depth.

Omon.phos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phos.comment: negative log10 of hydrogen ion concentration with the concentration expressed as mol H kg-1.

Omon.phyc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phyc.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "sum of phytoplankton carbon component concentrations.  In most (all?) cases this is the sum of phycdiat and phycmisc (i.e., 'Diatom Carbon Concentration' and 'Non-Diatom Phytoplankton Carbon Concentration'"
Omon.phyc.comment: sum of phytoplankton carbon component concentrations.  In most (all?) cases this is the sum of phycdiat and phycmisc (i.e., "Diatom Carbon Concentration" and "Non-Diatom Phytoplankton Carbon Concentration"
Omon.phyc.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.phycalc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phycalc.comment: carbon concentration from calcareous (calcite-producing) phytoplankton component alone
Omon.phycalc.long_name: Mole Concentration of Calcareous Phytoplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
Omon.phycalc.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.phycalcos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phycalcos.comment: carbon concentration from calcareous (calcite-producing) phytoplankton component alone
Omon.phycalcos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Calcareous Phytoplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.phycos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phycos.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "sum of phytoplankton organic carbon component concentrations at the sea surface"
Omon.phycos.comment: sum of phytoplankton carbon component concentrations.  In most (all?) cases this is the sum of phycdiat and phycmisc (i.e., "Diatom Carbon Concentration" and "Non-Diatom Phytoplankton Carbon Concentration"

Omon.phydiat.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Omon.phydiatos.comment: carbon from the diatom phytoplankton component concentration alone
Omon.phydiatos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Diatoms Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.phydiazos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phydiazos.comment: carbon concentration from the diazotrophic phytoplankton component alone
Omon.phydiazos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Diazotrophs Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.phymisc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phymisc.comment: carbon concentration from additional phytoplankton component alone
Omon.phymisc.long_name: Mole Concentration of Miscellaneous Phytoplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.phymiscos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phymiscos.comment: carbon concentration from additional phytoplankton component alone
Omon.phymiscos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Miscellaneous Phytoplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.phypico.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phypico.comment: carbon concentration from the picophytoplankton (<2 um) component alone
Omon.phypico.long_name: Mole Concentration of Picophytoplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water
Omon.phypico.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.phypicoos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.phypicoos.comment: carbon concentration from the picophytoplankton (<2 um) component alone
Omon.phypicoos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Picophytoplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.po4.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.po4.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. 'Dissolved inorganic phosphorus' means the sum of all inorganic phosphorus in solution (including phosphate, hydrogen phosphate, dihydrogen phosphate, and phosphoric acid)."
Omon.po4.comment: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called "molarity", and is used in the construction "mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y", where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as "nitrogen" or a phrase such as "nox_expressed_as_nitrogen". "Dissolved inorganic phosphorus" means the sum of all inorganic phosphorus in solution (including phosphate, hydrogen phosphate, dihydrogen phosphate, and phosphoric acid).
Omon.po4.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.pp.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.pp.comment: total primary (organic carbon) production by phytoplankton
Omon.pp.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.ppos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.ppos.comment: total primary (organic carbon) production by phytoplankton
Omon.ppos.processing_note:
Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

Omon.pso.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.pso.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere.  'Sea water pressure' is the pressure that exists in the medium of sea water.  It includes the pressure due to overlying sea water, sea ice, air and any other medium that may be present."
Omon.pso.comment: The surface called "surface" means the lower boundary of the atmosphere.  "Sea water pressure" is the pressure that exists in the medium of sea water.  It includes the pressure due to overlying sea water, sea ice, air and any other medium that may be present.
Omon.pso.long_name: Sea Water Pressure at Sea Water Surface
Omon.pso.processing_note: CMIP5 had units of dbar.  CMIP6 uses Pa. Report on native horizontal grid as well as on a spherical latitude/longitude grid.

Omon.scint.comment: This is a fundamental aspect of the changes in the hydrological cycle and their impact on the oceans, and due to new numerical schemes and vertical discretizations, it is important to calculate it consistently with the model formulation.
Omon.scint.long_name: Integral wrt depth of seawater practical salinity expressed as salt mass content
Omon.scint.processing_note: CHANGE: This is a new variable, which aids in understanding hydrological change. It is preferable to calculate it online, due to difficulties with vertical discretizations. It is calculated as an integral over hydrostatic pressure ranges, which makes it directly comparable with observations.

Omon.sduo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.sduo.comment: The eastward component of the net drift velocity of ocean water caused by surface wind-sea waves. The Stokes drift velocity could be defined as the difference between the average Lagrangian flow velocity of a fluid parcel, and the average Eulerian flow velocity of the fluid at a fixed position.

Omon.sdvo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.sdvo.comment: The northward component of the net drift velocity of ocean water caused by surface wind-sea waves. The Stokes drift velocity could be defined as the difference between the average Lagrangian flow velocity of a fluid parcel, and the average Eulerian flow velocity of the fluid at a fixed position.

Omon.sf6.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.sf6.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. The chemical formula of sulfur hexafluoride is SF6."
Omon.sf6.comment: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called "molarity", and is used in the construction "mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y", where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as "nitrogen" or a phrase such as "nox_expressed_as_nitrogen". The chemical formula of sulfur hexafluoride is SF6.
Omon.sf6.long_name: Mole Concentration of SF6 in Sea Water
Omon.sf6.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid as well as on a spherical latitude/longitude grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Omon.sfacrossline.cell_methods: area: mean where sea depth: sum where sea time: mean
Omon.sfacrossline.comment: Depth-integrated total salt mass transport from resolved and parameterized processes across different lines on the Earth's surface (based on appendix J and table J1 of Griffies et al., 2016). Formally, this means the integral along the line of the normal component of the heat transport. Positive and negative numbers refer to total northward/eastward and southward/westward transports, respectively. The transport should be evaluated for the full depth of the ocean, except for the Pacific Equatorial Undercurrent, which is averaged from the surface to 350m.
Omon.sfacrossline.long_name: Ocean Salt Mass Transport across Lines

Omon.sfdsi.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.sfdsi.comment: This field is physical, and it arises since sea ice has a nonzero salt content, so it exchanges salt with the liquid ocean upon melting and freezing.
Omon.sfdsi.long_name: Downward Sea Ice Basal Salt Flux
Omon.sfdsi.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid as well as mapped onto sphere.

Omon.sfriver.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.sfriver.comment: This field is physical, and it arises when rivers carry a nonzero salt content.  Often this is zero, with rivers assumed to be fresh.
Omon.sfriver.long_name: Salt Flux into Sea Water from Rivers
Omon.sfriver.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid as well as mapped onto sphere.

Omon.sfx.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.sfx.comment: Contains all contributions to 'x-ward' salt mass transport from resolved and parameterized processes. Report on native horizontal grid.
Omon.sfx.processing_note:
3d field. If only the 2d vertically integrated transport is available or is preferred, produce Omon.sfxint instead.
Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native. Report on native horizontal grid.

Omon.sfxint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea depth: sum where sea time: mean
Omon.sfxint.comment: Ocean salt mass x transport vertically integrated over the whole ocean depth. Contains all contributions to 'x-ward' salt mass transport from resolved and parameterized processes. Report on native horizontal grid.
Omon.sfxint.long_name: Vertically Integrated Ocean Salt Mass X Transport
Omon.sfxint.processing_note:
2d vertically integrated field. If the full 3d transport is preferred, produce Omon.sfx instead.
Report on native horizontal grid.

Omon.sfy.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.sfy.comment: Contains all contributions to 'y-ward' salt mass transport from resolved and parameterized processes. Report on native horizontal grid.
Omon.sfy.processing_note:
3d field. If only the 2d vertically integrated transport is available or is preferred, produce Omon.sfyint instead. 
Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native. Report on native horizontal grid.

Omon.sfyint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea depth: sum where sea time: mean
Omon.sfyint.comment: Ocean salt mass y transport vertically integrated over the whole ocean depth. Contains all contributions to 'y-ward' salt mass transport from resolved and parameterized processes. Report on native horizontal grid.
Omon.sfyint.long_name: Vertically Integrated Ocean Salt Mass Y Transport
Omon.sfyint.processing_note:
2d vertically integrated field. If the full 3d transport is preferred, produce Omon.sfy instead.
Report on native horizontal grid.

Omon.si.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.si.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called 'molarity', and is used in the construction 'mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y', where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. 'Dissolved inorganic silicon' means the sum of all inorganic silicon in solution (including silicic acid and its first dissociated anion SiO(OH)3-)."
Omon.si.comment: Mole concentration means number of moles per unit volume, also called "molarity", and is used in the construction "mole_concentration_of_X_in_Y", where X is a material constituent of Y. A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as "nitrogen" or a phrase such as "nox_expressed_as_nitrogen". "Dissolved inorganic silicon" means the sum of all inorganic silicon in solution (including silicic acid and its first dissociated anion SiO(OH)3-).
Omon.si.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.sios.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

A chemical or biological species denoted by X may be described by a single term such as 'nitrogen' or a phrase such as 'nox_expressed_as_nitrogen'. 'Dissolved inorganic silicon' means the sum of all inorganic silicon in solution (including silicic acid and its first dissociated anion SiO(OH)3-)."

Omon.sltbasin.cell_methods: longitude: sum (basin sum [along zig-zag grid path]) depth: sum time: mean
Omon.sltbasin.comment: Northward Ocean Salt Transport from all physical processes affecting northward salt transport, resolved and parameterized. Diagnosed here as a function of latitude and basin.

Omon.sltovgyre.cell_methods: longitude: sum (basin sum [along zig-zag grid path]) depth: sum time: mean
Omon.sltovgyre.cmip6_differences: "cell_methods" was "longitude: sum (comment: basin sum [along zig-zag grid path]) depth: sum time: mean"
Omon.sltovgyre.comment: From all advective mass transport processes, resolved and parameterized.
Omon.sltovgyre.long_name: Northward Ocean Salt Transport Due to Gyre
Omon.sltovgyre.processing_note:
For models which do not have a Cartesian lat-long grid, this transport can be approximated as thetransport across zig-zag paths corresponding to latitudes with spacing between latitudes appropriate tothe model's resolution, as is done for the ocean meridional overturning mass streamfunction.

Omon.sltovovrt.processing_note:

However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand. "
Omon.sossq.comment: Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.

Omon.spco2.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.spco2.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium. The partial pressure of a gaseous constituent of air is the pressure which it alone would exert with unchanged temperature and number of moles per unit volume. The chemical formula for carbon dioxide is CO2."
Omon.spco2.comment: The surface called "surface" means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. The partial pressure of a dissolved gas in sea water is the partial pressure in air with which it would be in equilibrium. The partial pressure of a gaseous constituent of air is the pressure which it alone would exert with unchanged temperature and number of moles per unit volume. The chemical formula for carbon dioxide is CO2.
Omon.spco2.long_name: Surface Aqueous Partial Pressure of CO2
Omon.spco2.processing_note:
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Dimensions - CMIP6:longitude latitude time depth0m CMIP7:longitude latitude time  depth0m,
 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

Omon.swh.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.swh.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This is a key parameter for describing wave energy and is derived from the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wave spectrum.

Omon.swhmax.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: maximum
Omon.swhmax.comment: Highest value of the significant wave height simulated within a given time range (e.g., daily or monthly). The significant wave height (swh) is derived from the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, swh is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wave spectrum.

Omon.swhswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.swhswell.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating just swell waves (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area). This parameter is derived from all swell partitions of the wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the components of the two-dimensional wave spectrum that are not under the influence of local wind.

Omon.swhwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.swhwindsea.comment: Average height of the highest one-third of waves present in the sea state, incorporating just wind-sea waves (i.e., local wind waves). It is derived from the wind-sea wave spectrum using spectral moments. Specifically, this parameter is four times the square root of the integral over all directions and all frequencies of the two-dimensional wind-sea wave spectrum.

Omon.talk.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.talk.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "total alkalinity equivalent concentration (including carbonate, nitrogen, silicate, and borate components)"
Omon.talk.comment: total alkalinity equivalent concentration (including carbonate, borate, phosphorus, silicon, and nitrogen components)
Omon.talk.processing_note: Concentrations of all 3D tracers in the uppermost ocean layer. See first table in Oyr for a complete list of these tracers.  "Tracer"  concentations should be reported even if they are diagnosed rather than prognostically calculated.

Omon.tauuo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Omon.tauuo.long_name: Sea Water Surface Downward X Stress
Omon.tauuo.processing_note:
Report on native horizontal grid.

Omon.thkcellvo.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid as well as on a spherical latitude/longitude grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Omon.vsf.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.vsf.comment: It is set to zero in models which receive a real water flux.
Omon.vsf.long_name: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water
Omon.vsf.processing_note: If this does not vary from one year to the next, report only a single year.  Positive flux implies correction increases salinity of water.  This includes all virtual salt flux, including that due to a salt flux correction.  Report on native horizontal grid.

Omon.vsfcorr.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.vsfcorr.comment: It is set to zero in models which receive a real water flux.

Omon.vsfevap.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.vsfevap.comment: zero for models using real water fluxes.
Omon.vsfevap.long_name: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water Due to Evaporation

Omon.vsfpr.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.vsfpr.comment: zero for models using real water fluxes.
Omon.vsfpr.long_name: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water Due to Rainfall

Omon.vsfriver.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.vsfriver.comment: zero for models using real water fluxes.
Omon.vsfriver.long_name: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water from Rivers

Omon.vsfsit.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.vsfsit.comment: This variable measures the virtual salt flux into sea water due to the melting of sea ice. It is set to zero in models which receive a real water flux.
Omon.vsfsit.long_name: Virtual Salt Flux into Sea Water Due to Sea Ice Thermodynamics
Omon.vsfsit.processing_note: The priority set by the WGOMD was 2 for this field.  The sea-ice folks requested that the priority be raised to 1. Report on native horizontal grid.

Omon.wdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wdir.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

Omon.wdirswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wdirswell.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the swell component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area). This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

Omon.wdirwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wdirwindsea.comment: Mean direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the wind-sea component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., local wind waves). This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

Omon.wfcorr.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wfcorr.comment: Computed as the water flux into the ocean due to flux correction divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell.
Omon.wfcorr.processing_note: If this does not vary from one year to the next, report only a single year.  Most models now have zero water flux adjustment, in which case ignore or report zero. Report on native horizontal grid as well as mapped onto sphere.

Omon.wfo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wfo.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Computed as the water flux into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell. This is the sum *wfonocorr* and *wfcorr*."
Omon.wfo.comment: Computed as the water flux into the ocean divided by the area of the ocean portion of the grid cell. This is the sum \*wfonocorr\* and \*wfcorr\*.
Omon.wfo.processing_note: net flux of water into sea water, including any flux correction. Report on native horizontal grid as well as mapped onto sphere.

Omon.wmo.cell_methods: area: sum where sea time: mean
Omon.wmo.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Upward mass transport from resolved and parameterized advective transport."
Omon.wmo.comment: Upward mass transport from residual mean (resolved plus parameterized) advective transport.
Omon.wmo.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native. Those who wish to record vertical velocities and vertical fluxes on ocean half-levels may do so. If using CMOR3 you will be required to specify artificial bounds (e.g. located at full model levels) to avoid an error exit.

Omon.wo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wo.cmip6_differences:
"cell_measures" was "--OPT"

"comment" was "A velocity is a vector quantity. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward)."

"cell_methods" was "time: mean"
Omon.wo.comment: Prognostic z-ward velocity component resolved by the model.
Omon.wo.processing_note:
Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native. Those who wish to record vertical velocities and vertical fluxes on ocean half-levels may do so. If using CMOR3 you will be required to specify artificial bounds (e.g. located at full model levels) to avoid an error exit.

Omon.wpdir.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wpdir.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the total wave energy spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves, by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is usually expressed in degrees relative to true north.

Omon.wpdirswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wpdirswell.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the swell component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area), by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is typically expressed in degrees relative to true north.

Omon.wpdirwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wpdirwindsea.comment: Direction of wave propagation (direction from which the wave is coming) derived from the wind-sea component of the wave energy spectrum (i.e., local wind waves), by identifying the direction associated with the peak (maximum) energy density. This variable is typically expressed in degrees relative to true north.

Omon.wpp.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wpp.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic waves in total wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves. In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across the entire two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating both wind-sea and swell waves.

Omon.wppswell.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wppswell.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic swell waves (i.e., waves that have propagated away from their generation area). In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across part of the two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating just swell waves.

Omon.wppwindsea.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.wppwindsea.comment: Wave period associated with the most energetic wind-sea waves (i.e., local wind waves). In spectral wind wave models, this represents the spectral peak across part of the two-dimensional wave spectrum, incorporating just wind-sea waves.

Omon.zmeso.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.zmeso.comment: carbon  concentration from mesozooplankton (20-200 um) component alone
Omon.zmeso.long_name: Mole Concentration of Mesozooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.zmesoos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.zmesoos.comment: carbon  concentration from mesozooplankton (20-200 um) component alone
Omon.zmesoos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Mesozooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.zmicro.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.zmicro.comment: carbon  concentration from the microzooplankton (<20 um) component alone
Omon.zmicro.long_name: Mole Concentration of Microzooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.zmicroos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.zmicroos.comment: carbon  concentration from the microzooplankton (<20 um) component alone
Omon.zmicroos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Microzooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.zmisc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Omon.zmiscos.comment: carbon from additional zooplankton component concentrations alone (e.g. Micro, meso).  Since the models all have different numbers of components, this variable has been included to provide a check for intercomparison between models since some phytoplankton groups are supersets.
Omon.zmiscos.long_name: Surface Mole Concentration of Other Zooplankton Expressed as Carbon in Sea Water

Omon.zooc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.zooc.comment: sum of zooplankton carbon component concentrations

Omon.zoocos.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Omon.zoocos.comment: sum of zooplankton carbon component concentrations

Omon.zossq.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid as well as on a spherical latitude/longitude grid.

Oyr.difmxybo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.difmxybo.comment: Lateral biharmonic viscosity applied to the momentum equations.
Oyr.difmxybo.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.difmxylo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Oyr.diftrblo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.diftrblo.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Ocean tracer diffusivity associated with parameterized eddy-induced advective transport. Sometimes this diffusivity is called the 'thickness' diffusivity. For CMIP5, this diagnostic was called 'ocean tracer bolus laplacian diffusivity'.  The CMIP6 name is physically more relevant."
Oyr.diftrblo.comment: Ocean tracer diffusivity associated with parameterized eddy-induced advective transport. Sometimes this diffusivity is called the "thickness" diffusivity. For CMIP5, this diagnostic was called "ocean tracer bolus laplacian diffusivity".  The CMIP6 name is physically more relevant.

Oyr.diftrelo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.diftrelo.comment: Ocean tracer diffusivity associated with parameterized eddy-induced diffusive transport oriented along neutral or isopycnal directions. Sometimes this diffusivity is called the neutral diffusivity or isopycnal diffusivity or Redi diffusivity.

Oyr.difvho.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Oyr.difvso.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Oyr.dispkexyfo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.dispkexyfo.comment: Depth integrated impacts on kinetic energy arising from lateral frictional dissipation associated with Laplacian and/or biharmonic viscosity. For CMIP5, this diagnostic was 3d, whereas the CMIP6 depth integrated diagnostic is sufficient for many purposes and reduces archive requirements.
Oyr.dispkexyfo.long_name: Ocean Kinetic Energy Dissipation per Unit Area Due to XY Friction

Oyr.ocontempdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.ocontempdiff.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized dianeutral mixing. Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.

Oyr.ocontempmint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Oyr.ocontemppsmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Oyr.ocontemppsmadvect.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.ocontemprmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.ocontemprmadvect.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Conservative Temperature is defined as part of the Thermodynamic Equation of Seawater 2010 (TEOS-10) which was adopted in 2010 by the International Oceanographic Commission (IOC). The phrase 'residual mean advection' refers to the sum of the model's resolved advective transport plus any parameterized advective transport. Parameterized advective transport includes processes such as parameterized mesoscale and submesoscale transport, as well as any other advectively parameterized transport. When the parameterized advective transport is represented in the model as a skew-diffusion rather than an advection, then the parameterized skew diffusion should be included in this diagnostic, since the convergence of skew-fluxes are identical (in the continuous formulation) to the convergence of advective fluxes."
Oyr.ocontemprmadvect.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from residual mean  (sum of Eulerian mean + parameterized eddy-induced) advection. Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.
Oyr.ocontemprmadvect.long_name: Tendency of Sea Water Conservative Temperature Expressed as Heat Content Due to Residual Mean Advection
Oyr.ocontemprmadvect.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.ocontemptend.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.ocontemptend.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from all processes. Reported only for models that use conservative temperature as prognostic field.
Oyr.ocontemptend.long_name: Tendency of Sea Water Conservative Temperature Expressed as Heat Content
Oyr.ocontemptend.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.opottempdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.opottempdiff.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized dianeutral mixing. Reported only for models that use potential temperature as prognostic field.
Oyr.opottempdiff.long_name: Tendency of Sea Water Potential Temperature Expressed as Heat Content Due to Parameterized Dianeutral Mixing
Oyr.opottempdiff.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.opottempmint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.opottempmint.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Integral over the full ocean depth of the product of sea water density and potential temperature."

"standard_name" was "integral_wrt_depth_of_product_of_sea_water_density_and_potential_temperature"
Oyr.opottempmint.comment: Full column sum of density\*cell thickness\*potential temperature. If the model is Boussinesq, then use Boussinesq reference density for the density factor.
Oyr.opottempmint.long_name: Integral with Respect to Depth of Product of Sea Water Density and Potential Temperature

Oyr.opottemppadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.opottemppadvect.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from parameterized eddy advection (any form of eddy advection). Reported only for models that use potential temperature as prognostic field."

When the parameterized advective transport is represented in the model as a skew-diffusion rather than an advection, then the parameterized skew diffusion should be included in this diagnostic, since the convergence of skew-fluxes are identical (in the continuous formulation) to the convergence of advective fluxes."

Oyr.osaltdiff.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.osaltpadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.osaltpadvect.comment: Tendency of salt content for a grid cell from parameterized eddy advection (any form of eddy advection).
Oyr.osaltpadvect.long_name: Tendency of Sea Water Salinity Expressed as Salt Content Due to Parameterized Eddy Advection
Oyr.osaltpadvect.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.osaltpmdiff.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

Oyr.osaltpmdiff.long_name: Tendency of Sea Water Salinity Expressed as Salt Content Due to Parameterized Mesoscale Diffusion
Oyr.osaltpmdiff.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.osaltpsmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.osaltpsmadvect.comment: Tendency of salt content for a grid cell from parameterized submesoscale eddy advection.

Oyr.osaltpsmadvect.processing_note: Report on native horizontal grid. Online mapping to depth/pressure vertical grid if depth or pressure are not native.

Oyr.osaltrmadvect.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.osaltrmadvect.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The phrase 'residual mean advection' refers to the sum of the model's resolved advective transport plus any parameterized advective transport. Parameterized advective transport includes processes such as parameterized mesoscale and submesoscale transport, as well as any other advectively parameterized transport. When the parameterized advective transport is represented in the model as a skew-diffusion rather than an advection, then the parameterized skew diffusion should be included in this diagnostic, since the convergence of skew-fluxes are identical (in the continuous formulation) to the convergence of advective fluxes."

Oyr.rsdoabsorb.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.rsdoabsorb.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "'shortwave' means shortwave radiation. 'Layer' means any layer with upper and lower boundaries that have constant values in some vertical coordinate. There must be a vertical coordinate variable indicating the extent of the layer(s). If the layers are model layers, the vertical coordinate can be model_level_number, but it is recommended to specify a physical coordinate (in a scalar or auxiliary coordinate variable) as well. Net absorbed radiation is the difference between absorbed and emitted radiation."
Oyr.rsdoabsorb.comment: Tendency of heat content for a grid cell from penetrative shortwave radiation within a grid cell.
Oyr.rsdoabsorb.long_name: Net Rate of Absorption of Shortwave Energy in Ocean Layer

Oyr.somint.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.somint.cmip6_differences:
"standard_name" was "integral_wrt_depth_of_product_of_sea_water_density_and_salinity"

"comment" was "Full column sum of density*cell thickness*prognostic salinity. If the model is Boussinesq, then use Boussinesq reference density for the density factor."
Oyr.somint.comment: Full column sum of density\*cell thickness\*salinity. If the model is Boussinesq, then use Boussinesq reference density for the density factor.
Oyr.somint.long_name: Depth Integral of Product of Sea Water Density and Prognostic Salinity

Oyr.tnkebto.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.tnkebto.comment: Depth integrated impacts on kinetic energy arising from parameterized eddy-induced advection. For CMIP5, this diagnostic was 3d, whereas the CMIP6 depth integrated diagnostic is sufficient for many purposes and reduces archive requirements.
Oyr.tnkebto.long_name: Tendency of Ocean Eddy Kinetic Energy Content Due to Parameterized Eddy Advection

Oyr.tnpeo.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
Oyr.tnpeo.comment: Rate that work is done against vertical stratification, as measured by the vertical heat and salt diffusivity. Report here as depth integrated two-dimensional field.
Oyr.tnpeo.long_name: Tendency of Ocean Potential Energy Content

Oyr.volcello.cell_methods: area: sum where sea time: mean
Oyr.volcello.comment: For oceans with more than 1 mesh (e.g. staggered grids), report areas that apply to surface vertical fluxes of energy. If this field is time-dependent then save it instead as one of your Omon and Odec fields
Oyr.volcello.processing_note: a 3-d field: For oceans with more than 1 mesh, report on grid that applies to temperature

SIday.siage.comment: Age of sea ice since its formation in open water.
SIday.siage.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siarean.comment: Total integrated area of sea ice in the Northern Hemisphere (where siconc > 0). Does not include grid cells partially covered by land.

SIday.siareas.comment: Total integrated area of sea ice in the Southern Hemisphere (where siconc > 0). Does not include grid cells partially covered by land.

SIday.siconc.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Percentage of grid cell covered by sea ice"

"cell_methods" was "area: mean where sea time: mean"
SIday.siconc.comment: Areal fraction of a given grid cell that is covered by sea ice on the ocean grid, independent of the thickness of that ice.
SIday.siconc.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Units (from Physical Parameter) - CMIP6:% CMIP7:1, CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: mean where sea time: mean CMIP7:area: time: mean,

SIday.siconca.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Percentage of grid cell covered by sea ice"
SIday.siconca.comment: Areal fraction of a given grid cell that is covered by sea ice on the atmosphere grid, independent of the thickness of that ice.
SIday.siconca.processing_note:
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Units (from Physical Parameter) - CMIP6:% CMIP7:1,
 Changes since reverted/fixed. Variable now matches CMIP6 definition.

SIday.siextentn.comment: Total integrated area of all Northern Hemisphere grid cells that are covered by at least 15% areal fraction of sea ice (siconc >= 0.15). Does not include grid cells partially covered by land.

SIday.siextents.comment: Total integrated area of all Southern Hemisphere grid cells that are covered by at least 15% areal fraction of sea ice (siconc >= 0.15). Does not include grid cells partially covered by land.

SIday.sifb.comment: Mean height of sea-ice surface (i.e. snow-ice interface when snow covered) above sea level. This follows the classical definition of freeboard for in situ observations. In the satellite community, sometimes the total height of sea ice and snow above sea level is referred to as freeboard. This can easily be calculated by adding sisnthick to sifb.
SIday.sifb.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siflcondbot.comment: Net heat conduction flux at the ice base, i.e. the conductive heat flux from the centre of the lowermost vertical sea-ice grid box to the base of the sea ice (energy flow per sea ice area). Positive for a downward heat flux.
SIday.siflcondbot.long_name: Net Conductive Heat Flux in Sea Ice at the Base
SIday.siflcondbot.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siflcondtop.comment: Net heat conduction flux at the ice surface, i.e. the conductive heat flux from the centre of the uppermost vertical sea-ice grid box to the surface of the sea ice (energy flow per sea ice area). Positive for a downward heat flux.
SIday.siflcondtop.long_name: Net Conductive Heat Flux in Sea Ice at the Surface
SIday.siflcondtop.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sifllattop.comment: Net latent heat flux over sea ice (energy flow per sea ice area). Positive for a downward heat flux.
SIday.sifllattop.long_name: Net Latent Heat Flux over Sea Ice
SIday.sifllattop.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sifllwdtop.comment: Downwelling longwave flux from the atmosphere to the sea-ice surface (energy flow per sea ice area). Always positive or zero.
SIday.sifllwdtop.long_name: Downwelling Longwave Flux over Sea Ice
SIday.sifllwdtop.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sifllwutop.comment: Upward longwave flux from the sea-ice surface to the atmosphere (energy flow per sea ice area). Always positive or zero.
SIday.sifllwutop.long_name: Upwelling Longwave Flux over Sea Ice
SIday.sifllwutop.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siflsensbot.comment: Net sensible heat flux under sea ice from or to the ocean (energy flow per sea ice area). Per sign convention, heat from the ocean is counted as negative since it describes an upward heat flux.
SIday.siflsensbot.long_name: Net Upward Sensible Heat Flux under Sea Ice
SIday.siflsensbot.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siflsenstop.comment: Net sensible heat flux over sea ice (energy flow per sea ice area). Positive for a downward heat flux.
SIday.siflsenstop.long_name: Net Downward Sensible Heat Flux over Sea Ice
SIday.siflsenstop.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siflswdbot.comment: Downwelling shortwave flux underneath sea ice, i.e. the amount of shortwave radiation that penetrates the sea ice and reaches the sea ice-ocean interface (energy flow per sea ice area). Always positive or zero.
SIday.siflswdbot.long_name: Downwelling Shortwave Flux under Sea Ice
SIday.siflswdbot.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siflswdtop.comment: Downwelling shortwave flux from the atmosphere to the sea-ice surface (energy flow per sea ice area). Always positive or zero.
SIday.siflswdtop.long_name: Downwelling Shortwave Flux over Sea Ice
SIday.siflswdtop.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siflswutop.comment: Upward shortwave flux from the sea-ice surface to the atmosphere (energy flow per sea ice area). Always positive or zero.
SIday.siflswutop.long_name: Upwelling Shortwave Flux over Sea Ice
SIday.siflswutop.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sihc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
SIday.sihc.comment: Heat content of all ice in grid cell divided by grid-cell area. This includes both the latent and sensible heat content contributions. Water at 0C is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J. This variable does not include heat content of snow, but does include heat content of brine. Heat content is always negative since both the sensible and the latent heat content of ice are less than that of water. Note that the CF standard name is incorrect since heat content is not only function of temperature but also of salinity, plus the link with temperature is not linear. A new CF standard name is currently being proposed to address this issue (https://github.com/cf-convention/vocabularies/issues/253).

SIday.siitdconc.comment: Area fraction of grid cell covered by each ice thickness category (vector with one entry for each ice thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of the categories as third coordinate axis).
SIday.siitdconc.long_name: Sea-Ice Area Fractions in Ice Thickness Categories

SIday.siitdsnconc.comment: Area fraction of grid cell covered by snow in each ice thickness category (vector with one entry for each ice thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of the categories as third coordinate axis).
SIday.siitdsnconc.long_name: Snow Area Fractions in Ice Thickness Categories

SIday.siitdsnthick.comment: Actual thickness of snow in each ice thickness category, NOT snow volume divided by grid area (vector with one entry for each ice thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of categories as third coordinate axis). It can also be derived by dividing the volume of snow by the area of snow in each thickness category.
SIday.siitdsnthick.long_name: Snow Thickness in Ice Thickness Categories
SIday.siitdsnthick.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.siitdthick.comment: Actual (floe) thickness of sea ice in each ice thickness category, NOT volume divided by grid area (vector with one entry for each ice thickness category starting from the thinnest category, netcdf file should use thickness bounds of categories as third coordinate axis).
SIday.siitdthick.long_name: Sea-Ice Thickness in Ice Thickness Categories
SIday.siitdthick.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.simpconc.comment: Area fraction of sea-ice surface that is covered by melt ponds.
SIday.simpconc.long_name: Fraction of Sea Ice Covered by Melt Pond

SIday.simpeffconc.comment: Area fraction of sea-ice surface that is covered by open melt ponds, that is melt ponds that are not covered by snow or ice lids. This represents the effective (i.e. radiatively-active) melt pond area fraction.
SIday.simpeffconc.long_name: Fraction of Sea Ice Covered by Effective Melt Pond

SIday.simprefrozen.comment: Volume of refrozen ice on melt ponds divided by melt pond covered area.
SIday.simprefrozen.long_name: Thickness of Refrozen Ice on Melt Pond
SIday.simprefrozen.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.simpthick.comment: Average depth of melt ponds on sea ice, that is melt pond volume divided by melt pond area.
SIday.simpthick.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sirdgconc.comment: Area fraction of sea-ice surface that is ridged sea ice.
SIday.sirdgconc.processing_note: Fraction of sea ice, by area, which is covered by sea ice ridges, giving equal weight to every square metre of sea ice.

SIday.sirdgthick.comment: Total volume of ridged sea ice divided by area of ridges, i.e. mean thickness of ridged sea ice.
SIday.sirdgthick.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sisali.comment: Mean sea-ice salinity of all sea ice in grid cell. Sometimes, models implicitly or explicitly assume a different salinity of the ice for thermodynamic considerations than they do for closing the salt budget with the ocean. In these cases, the mean salinity used in the calculation of the salt budget should be reported.
SIday.sisali.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sisaltmass.comment: Total mass of all salt in sea ice divided by grid-cell area. Sometimes, models implicitly or explicitly assume a different salinity of the ice for thermodynamic considerations than they do for closing the salt budget with the ocean. In these cases, the total mass of all salt in sea ice should be calculated from the salinity value used in the calculation of the salt budget.
SIday.sisaltmass.long_name: Mass of Salt in Sea Ice
SIday.sisaltmass.processing_note: Total mass of all salt in sea ice divided by grid-cell area

SIday.sisnhc.comment: Heat content of all snow in grid cell divided by grid-cell area. This includes both the latent and sensible heat content contributions. Snow-water equivalent at 0 C is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J. Does not include the heat content of sea ice.

SIday.sisnmassn.comment: Total integrated mass of snow on sea ice in the Northern Hemisphere.
SIday.sisnmassn.long_name: Snow Mass on Sea Ice North

SIday.sisnmasss.comment: Total integrated mass of snow on sea ice in the Southern Hemisphere.
SIday.sisnmasss.long_name: Snow Mass on Sea Ice South

SIday.sisnthick.cell_methods: area: mean where snow over sea_ice area: time: mean where sea_ice
SIday.sisnthick.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "Actual thickness of snow (snow volume divided by snow-covered area)"
SIday.sisnthick.comment: Actual thickness of snow averaged over the snow-covered part of the sea ice. This thickness is usually directly available within the model formulation. It can also be derived by dividing the total volume of snow by the area of the snow.
SIday.sisnthick.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SIday.sispeed.cmip6_differences:
"cell_methods" was "area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)"

"comment" was "Speed of ice (i.e. mean absolute velocity) to account for back-and-forth movement of the ice"

SImon.siareaacrossline.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)"
SImon.siareaacrossline.comment: Net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean. Note that the definitions of the passages are for SIMIP purposes just meant as default values as given by the physical ocean MIP described in Griffies et al. (2016). Individual models might chose slightly different definitions as given by their grid geometry. 1. Fram Strait: (11.5W,81.3N) to (10.5E,79.6N). 2. Canadian Arctic Archipelago: (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N). 3. Barents Sea Opening: (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N). 4. Bering Strait: (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N).

"comment" was "Computed strength of the ice pack, defined as the energy (J m-2) dissipated per unit area removed from the ice pack under compression, and assumed proportional to the change in potential energy caused by ridging. For Hibler-type models, this is P (= P*h exp(-C(1-A)) where P* is compressive strength, h ice thickness, A compactness and C strength reduction constant)."
SImon.sicompstren.comment: Computed strength of the ice pack, defined as the energy (J m-2) dissipated per unit area removed from the ice pack under compression, and assumed proportional to the change in potential energy caused by ridging. For Hibler-type models, this is P = P\* h exp(-C(1-A)) where P\* is compressive strength, h is ice thickness, A is compactness and C is strength reduction constant.
SImon.sicompstren.processing_note:
Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) CMIP7:area: time: mean where sea_ice (mask=siconc),

SImon.sidmassevapsubl.comment: Rate of change of sea-ice mass change through evaporation and sublimation divided by grid-cell area. If a model does not differentiate between the sublimation of snow and sea ice, we recommend to report sidmassevapsubl as zero as long as the ice is snow covered, and to report any sublimation within the variable sisndmasssubl.
SImon.sidmassevapsubl.long_name: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Evaporation and Sublimation

SImon.sidmassgrowthbot.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
SImon.sidmassgrowthbot.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The rate of change of sea ice mass due to vertical growth of existing sea ice at its base divided by grid-cell area."
SImon.sidmassgrowthbot.comment: Rate of change of sea-ice mass due to vertical growth of existing sea ice at its base divided by grid-cell area. Note that this number is always positive or zero since sea-ice melt is collected in sidmassmeltbot. This is to account for differential growth and melt in models with a sub-grid scale ice thickness distribution.
SImon.sidmassgrowthbot.long_name: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Basal Growth

SImon.sidmassgrowthsi.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The rate of change of sea ice mass due to transformation of snow to sea ice divided by grid-cell area"

SImon.sidmassgrowthsi.long_name: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Snow-to-Ice Conversion

SImon.sidmassgrowthwat.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

SImon.sidmassgrowthwat.comment: Rate of change of sea-ice mass due to sea ice formation in supercooled water (often through frazil formation) divided by grid-cell area. Always positive or zero.
SImon.sidmassgrowthwat.long_name: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Growth in Supercooled Open Water (Frazil)

SImon.sidmassmeltbot.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean

SImon.sidmassmeltbot.comment: Rate of change of sea-ice mass through melting/dissolution at the ice bottom divided by grid-cell area. Note that this number is always zero or negative since sea-ice growth is collected in sidmassgrowthbot. This is to account for differential growth and melt in models with a sub-grid scale ice thickness distribution.
SImon.sidmassmeltbot.long_name: Sea-Ice Mass Change Through Bottom Melting

SImon.sifb.comment: Mean height of sea-ice surface (i.e. snow-ice interface when snow covered) above sea level. This follows the classical definition of freeboard for in situ observations. In the satellite community, sometimes the total height of sea ice and snow above sea level is referred to as freeboard. This can easily be calculated by adding sisnthick to sifb.

(2016) for more detail.

SImon.siflfwbot.cmip6_differences:

"comment" was "Total flux of fresh water from water into sea ice divided by grid-cell area; This flux is negative during ice growth (liquid water mass decreases, hence upward flux of freshwater), positive during ice melt (liquid water mass increases, hence downward flux of freshwater)"
SImon.siflfwbot.comment: Total flux of fresh water from water into sea ice divided by grid-cell area. This flux is positive when fresh water enters the ocean, and is therefore negative during ice growth and positive during ice melt.
SImon.siflfwbot.processing_note:
Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.

SImon.siflfwdrain.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Total flux of fresh water from sea-ice surface into underlying ocean. This combines both surface melt water that drains directly into the ocean and the drainage of surface melt pond. By definition, this flux is always positive."

"cell_methods" was "area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)"
SImon.siflfwdrain.comment: Total flux of fresh water from sea-ice surface into underlying ocean divided by grid-cell area. This combines both surface meltwater that drains directly into the ocean and the drainage of surface melt ponds. By definition, this flux is always positive.
SImon.siflfwdrain.processing_note:
Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). Hence, all time samples with non-zero sea-ice fraction are first multiplied by area fraction, then summed, and then divided by the sum of the area fractions. See Appendix C of Notz et al. (2016) for more detail.
CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) CMIP7:area: time: mean where sea_ice (mask=siconc),

SImon.sihc.cell_methods: area: mean where sea time: mean
SImon.sihc.cmip6_differences:
"standard_name" was "sea_ice_temperature_expressed_as_heat_content"

"comment" was "Heat content of all ice in grid cell divided by total grid-cell area. Water at 0 Celsius is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J.  Does not include heat content of snow, but does include heat content of brine. Heat content is always negative, since both the sensible and the latent heat content of ice are less than that of water"

"long_name" was "Sea-Ice Heat Content per Unit Area"
SImon.sihc.comment: Heat content of all ice in grid cell divided by grid-cell area. This includes both the latent and sensible heat content contributions. Water at 0C is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J. This variable does not include heat content of snow, but does include heat content of brine. Heat content is always negative since both the sensible and the latent heat content of ice are less than that of water. Note that the CF standard name is incorrect since heat content is not only function of temperature but also of salinity, plus the link with temperature is not linear. A new CF standard name is currently being proposed to address this issue (https://github.com/cf-convention/vocabularies/issues/253).

SImon.simassacrossline.cmip6_differences:
"long_name" was "Sea Mass Area Flux Through Straits"

"comment" was "net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)"
SImon.simassacrossline.comment: Net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice mass transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean. Note that the definitions of the passages are for SIMIP purposes just meant as default values as given by the physical ocean MIP described in Griffies et al. (2016). Individual models might chose slightly different definitions as given by their grid geometry. 1. Fram Strait: (11.5W,81.3N) to (10.5E,79.6N). 2. Canadian Arctic Archipelago: (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N). 3. Barents Sea Opening: (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N). 4. Bering Strait: (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N).

SImon.sino3.processing_note: Note that SIMIP requests the area-weighted average for all intensive variables (i.e., variables that are not proportional to area fraction such as albedo, temperature, or heat flux). (2016) for more detail.

SImon.sisndmasssnf.comment: Rate of change of snow mass due to solid precipitation (i.e. snowfall) falling onto sea ice divided by grid-cell area. Always positive or zero.

SImon.sisndmasssubl.comment: Rate of change of snow mass through sublimation divided by grid-cell area. If a model does not differentiate between the sublimation of snow and sea ice, we recommend to report all sublimation within sisndmasssubl as long as the ice is snow covered.

SImon.sisnhc.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Heat-content of all snow in grid cell divided by total grid-cell area. Snow-water equivalent at 0 Celsius is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J.  Does not include heat content of sea ice."

"long_name" was "Snow Heat Content per Unit Area"

"cell_methods" was "area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)"
SImon.sisnhc.comment: Heat content of all snow in grid cell divided by grid-cell area. This includes both the latent and sensible heat content contributions. Snow-water equivalent at 0 C is assumed to have a heat content of 0 J. Does not include the heat content of sea ice.
SImon.sisnhc.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) CMIP7:area: time: mean where sea_ice (mask=siconc),

SImon.sisnmass.cmip6_differences:
"comment" was "Total mass of snow on sea ice divided by sea-ice area."

"cell_methods" was "area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc)"
SImon.sisnmass.comment: Total mass of snow on sea ice divided by grid-cell area. This then allows one to analyse the storage of latent heat in the snow, and to calculate the snow-water equivalent.
SImon.sisnmass.processing_note: CHANGE SINCE CMIP6 in Cell Methods - CMIP6:area: time: mean where sea_ice (comment: mask=siconc) CMIP7:area: time: mean where sea_ice (mask=siconc),

SImon.sisnmassacrossline.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "net (sum of transport in all directions) sea ice area transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean 1. Fram Strait = (11.5W,81.3N to (10.5E,79.6N) 2. Canadian Archipelago = (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N) 3. Barents opening = (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N) 4. Bering Strait = (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N)"
SImon.sisnmassacrossline.comment: Net (sum of transport in all directions) snow mass transport through the following four passages, positive into the Arctic Ocean. Note that the definitions of the passages are for SIMIP purposes just meant as default values as given by the physical ocean MIP described in Griffies et al. (2016). Individual models might chose slightly different definitions as given by their grid geometry. 1. Fram Strait: (11.5W,81.3N) to (10.5E,79.6N). 2. Canadian Arctic Archipelago: (128.2W,70.6N) to (59.3W,82.1N). 3. Barents Sea Opening: (16.8E,76.5N) to (19.2E,70.2N). 4. Bering Strait: (171W,66.2N) to (166W,65N).

SImon.sisnmasss.long_name: Snow Mass on Sea Ice South

day.hfls.cmip6_differences: "comment" was "The surface called 'surface' means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. 'Upward' indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface latent heat flux is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air on account of evaporation (including sublimation). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, 'flux' implies per unit area, called 'flux density' in physics."
day.hfls.comment: The surface called "surface" means the lower boundary of the atmosphere. "Upward" indicates a vector component which is positive when directed upward (negative downward). The surface latent heat flux is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air on account of evaporation (including sublimation). In accordance with common usage in geophysical disciplines, "flux" implies per unit area, called "flux density" in physics.

day.hfss.comment: The surface sensible heat flux, also called turbulent heat flux, is the exchange of heat between the surface and the air by motion of air.
